title: Making publishing work for you
body:
In the first module you explored how to make transparency work for you. You learned the benefits of publishing open data for local authorities and gained the ability to publish a 'minimum viable product' open dataset. In this module, we take a look at some of the ways you can publish better quality data and take you through the 12 steps of publishing a complete, high-quality dataset.

In this module you will learn:

  • The importance of ensuring the data you publish is clean and consistent
  • The major factors affecting consistent publication
  • The 12 steps to publishing high-quality open data

This module also provides useful links to supporting documents and services that can help save time and improve your publication.

title: Why does quality matter?
body:
Open data is designed to be used. Whether this use is by a developer to create a new app, a community group to deliver a better service or a citizen to improve accountability, they need to be able to quickly understand and use the dataset.

Publishing good quality data is the key to encouraging greater re-use. Improving the quality of your open data starts before you publish, by cleaning up entries and correctly formatting the data. You can also raise quality by making the data easier for people to find. Finally, through links and promotion, you can generate a bigger audience.

Creating better quality data is best done by following a process. Below you can learn why these steps matter before following the complete 12-step process yourself.

title: How can I improve the quality of my dataset for publication?
displayTitle: How can I improve the quality of my dataset for publication?
body:
The better the quality of your datasets, the better the reception from users. The most important thing is to publish. You can always improve the quality of your data later. Unfortunately, errors and inconsistencies will always occur in data. Consumers of data are sympathetic to these errors and often willing to help in correcting them through 'crowdsourcing'. Overall, public perception favours those who publish, regardless of quality, over those who don't.

Common errors include incorrect content, duplicate entries, missing data, inconsistent use of abbreviations, spelling mistakes and different data formats. In the next section you can find out how to spot these errors in your own data.

Fortunately there are free, purpose-built cleaning tools designed to deal with messy data. We recommend OpenRefine which can help you quickly and securely clean large datasets. Unlike Excel and other spreadsheet programmes, OpenRefine allows you to record the changes you make and can even automatically apply cleaning functions to other datasets. Importantly, you can share your record of changes with everyone, including other staff, so that your colleagues can benefit from your cleaning.

To get started with OpenRefine, follow our exercise here.

title: Common data quality challenges for local authority data
displayTitle: Common data quality challenges for local authority data
body: When looking at the quality of your own data, there are a number of common errors you should check for. There are also some unique challenges for local authorities. Below you can find details of the most common errors experienced by local authority publishers.

_items.title: Wrong date formats
_items.body:
Dates can be written in inconsistent ways. Mixed date formats are sometimes simple to spot:

8-sep-2013 vs 8/9/2013

and sometimes less obvious:

8/9/2013 vs 9/8/2013.

An additional challenge is that some applications, like Excel, will ‘guess’ the format when a dataset is opened which can hide how dates are actually written in the file.

The most common error is the mixed use of American (MM/DD/YYYY) and European (DD/MM/YYYY) formats.

_items.title: Incorrect geographic coordinates
_items.body: When publishing data to LGA standards, GeoX should hold the longitude or easting. GeoY should hold the latitude or northing. The two fields should be included in that order: GeoX then GeoY from left to right. All georeferences should also use either European Terrestrial Reference System (ETRS) 89 or World Geodetic System (WGS) 84 specification. Some publishers have used previous versions such as WGS 66. Make sure all your geodata is in ETRS89 or WGS84 using this helpful guide.

_items.title: Misspelt headings
_items.body: Column headings (aka field names) in your dataset must precisely match those of the relevant schema. The next module of this set provides extensive guidance on how to locate and use schamas. You need to make sure that the right capital letters and spelling are used to match the schema.

_items.title: Currency notation
_items.body: Price or cost data should not contain any prefix or suffix to the numeric value. For example, some publishers add a '£' sign before a value or 'GBP' afterward. Specify the correct column heading then only put numbers in price or cost fields.

title: Choosing where to publish
body: Your publishing location provides the gateway for access for your users. When choosing where to publish, start by thinking about how people will search and/or discover the data and consider carefully the following:

_items.title: Consider a platform
_items.body: Platforms can simplify the process of publishing your data. You may already have a data or content publishing platform that is suitable for your needs. If so you can publish there. If you don't have a platform, you may want to consider some examples used by other authorities such as CIPFA/Redbridge's Datashare, DataPress, Swirrl's PublishMyData, CKAN or Socrata to simplify the process of publishing.

_items.alt: Add an open data page to your site
_items.title: Add an open data page to your site
_items.body: It is a good idea to publish data on your own website, giving it a home. Make a small section and navigation header that will help people discover data. Make sure the data section is visible from anywhere on your site.

_items.title: Include links across your site
_items.body: Once the data has a home, people need to find it. It is unlikely that everyone will discover your data by browsing to it directly. Most of your users will search (using a search engine) and hit some page on your (or someone else's) website. It is important to include links to the data on all relevant pages where data has been used to help people navigate their way to the raw data.

title: Making data easier to discover
body: Another key aspect of data quality is how easily people can find your data. The following areas all contribute to making your data easier for users to discover.

_items.title: Providing a consistent location
_items.body:
You should provide your data under a consistent address or URL. This URL should also contain a set of characters which let users locate your data quickly and easily. These common characters are called 'Uniform Resource Identifiers' or URIs. We recommend using a URL for your dataset that uses the LGA's directory of common identifiers to refer to your local authority. You can use the LGA directory to look up the correct code for your authority in seconds. For example, Norfolk County Council has the idenfitier - 'http://opendatacommunities.org/doc/county-council/norfolk'.

You can also add another URL that redirects to the main one if you want to be more informative about the dataset. For example, a dataset from Hampshire county council about senior salaries might use a URL like 'http://www3.hants.gov.uk/opendata/datasets/senior-salaries.htm' that tells people exactly what the data is about from the address bar.

_items.alt: Optimise your data for search engines and aggregators
_items.title: Optimising your data for search engines and aggregators
_items.body: Most people today will use either a search engine to look for data or will visit an aggregator like LG open data pages. Search engines need to be able to find all the relevant details about your datasets. It is important to include good metadata alongside your data and allow search engines to harvest this data and make it easy for people to find your data this way. For an example of how to optimise your metadata for search engines you can look at this simple Google guide.

_items.title: Updating your inventory
_items.body: An inventory is a record of all the open datasets published by a local authority. Inventories are read by automatic harvesters, which constantly search for new or updated datasets to add to collections like the LG open data pages. The LG open data pages harvest the datasets published by local authorities across the UK. To allow this harvesting your dataset, you need to keep your inventory up-to-date. To find out how to publish a good inventory you can navigate to this page. The inventory encourages consistent referencing of datasets across councils to make it easier to find datasets on the same topic or in the same format. Your inventory entry can even be used to automatically update your datasets on data.gov.uk.

_items.alt: Register the dataset in a catalogue
_items.title: Registering the dataset in a catalogue
_items.body:
A catalogue is a collection of datasets published by different sources. There are a wide variety of catalogues maintained by different organisations that can automatically harvest your data once good metadata is provided. For authorities, there are two catalogues which it is particularly important to add your data to.

The first is data.gov.uk, the UK's national open data portal with a huge community of users. Registration is simple and requires only key metadata information. Click here for a step-by-step guide to registering your dataset

The second is local government open data pages, the community resource for local authority data. Registration with local government open data pages is automatic once you have an up-to-date inventory.

_items.title: Increasing the number of links
_items.body: On the web, links are key. The more links you have to your data, from more different sites, the easier your data will be to find. The best way of achieving greater numbers of links is through exposing your data in others' catalogues, like data.gov.uk and http://datasets.opendata.esd.org.uk/. Another way to increase your links is to use consistent URLs. By doing so you allow other data to be linked to yours through services like http://opendatacommunities.org/

title: How to publish your dataset: the full process
displayTitle: How to publish your dataset: the full process
instruction: Follow the steps below to publish a consistent, high-quality dataset.

_items.title: 1. Decide what to publish
_items.body: The first step is to decide what you wish to publish. Identify a list of datasets and prioritise them based on the demand from prospective users. Consider whether any of the prospective datasets are frequent FoI requests. These datasets can generate substantial efficiency savings and boost transparency.

_items.title: 2. Identify the right schema
_items.body: Once you have a dataset selected, you need to find the right schema to organise and name the column headings. LGA publish comprehensive schemas and you should use these wherever possible. The next module in this series provides complete guidance on choosing schemas.

_items.title: 3. Prepare the data
_items.body: With your schema selected, you need to prepare your dataset. Make sure all data is under the appropriate column headings, no entries are missing and that you have cleaned the data. Check the 'common data quality' section above for the most common errors to check for. Ensure your dataset is saved in an appropriate format, usually CSV.

_items.title: 4. Redact the data
_items.body: Once your data is prepared, you need to redact any entries that are exempt from publication. Redaction should be applied in line with the existing guidance for FoI requests. Full guidance on redaction can be found in the National Archives Redaction Toolkit.

_items.title: 5. Validate the data internally
_items.body: Once the data is prepared, have a colleague check your work. A new set of eyes will highlight any remaining issues with the data.

_items.title: 6. Add the appropriate licence
_items.body: Once that data has been validated, add the appropriate licence. We recommend using the Open Government Licence for all datasets unless there is a specific requirement with the data to use another licence. See module 1 for a walkthough of how to license your data appropriately.

_items.title: 7. Pick the publishing location(s)
_items.body: With the right licence in place, it is time to decide where the data should be published. We reccomend creating an open data page on your website. You may also wish to use a publishing platform to simplify the process. Check the section above on 'choosing where to publish' for further guidance. You also need to ensure that your dataset sits under a consistent URL that matches the LGA's resources. See the section above on 'improving visibility' for how to create the right URL.

_items.title: 8. Load and publish the data
_items.body: Time to take the data live on your chosen location(s). Upload the dataset to the website and/or publish it using your platform. Check the dataset is live, can be downloaded by anyone and displays correctly after download.

_items.title: 9. Validate externally
_items.body: Now the data is live, it is time to check that your upload matches the accected guidelines. Use the LGA Validator to check your dataset matches up.

_items.title: 10. Update your inventory
_items.body: As soon as you validate your new release with the LGA, you need to update your inventory to make your data visible to harvesters. Check the section above on 'improving visibility' for details on how to do this.

_items.title: 11. Register with catalogues
_items.body: In addition to updating your inventory, you need to let data.gov.uk and LGA open data pages know about your new dataset. Again the 'imrpoving visibility' section will tell you what you need to do.

_items.title: 12. Promote your work
_items.body: Your dataset is now out there, registered in the right places and high quality. The final step is to promote your release to the world. Create a blog post or press release to let people know and make sure you flag the new data on social media. If you are aware of any open data user communities, it is also a good idea to get in touch with them and invite them to try out the new data.

title: The benefits of publishing open data consistently - Local authority case studies
displayTitle: The benefits of publishing open data consistently - Local authority case studies
body: Local authorities have already seen benefits of following the consistent approaches above when publishing open data. The LGA keeps an extensive collection of case studies that catalogue these impacts. Below are some examples of local authority benefits.
instruction: Click the forward arrow for more.Select the ‘+’ sign to explore further, then swipe the image to see more.

_items.title: Learning from others: London Borough of Barnet
_items.body: London Borough of Barnet is a diverse metropolitan authority. Using LGA publishing guidelines, Barnet has now created a dedicated open data platform using Datapress. The platform currently hosts in excess of 180 datasets for the local area. Following LGA publishing guidelines helped Barnet save staff time and money by simplifying their publishing processes. To discover more about Barnet's experience read their case study or visit their open data portal.

_items.title: Building a simple data page: Wycombe District Council
_items.body: Wycombe council is an example of how to build a simple, informative open data page on your website. The page clearly displays the appropriate licence, links to external guides and provides links to pages under well-described URLs that can be found by search engines.

_items.title: Making it easy for users: North Somerset Council
_items.body: North Somerset Council used LGA guidance to publish more than 50 datasets in the Datashare platform. North Somerset's publication of clean, usable data in a single location enabled developer Eros Digital to produce the Discover North Somerset site. The website consumes a wide range of open data from tourist sites and transport links to events and hotels. The site now supports the local tourist economy, a key source of income for the area. The North Somerset example also demonstrates how publishing data based on demand from local people can create instant, tangible results.

title: Make publishing work for you
body:
In this module we have explored how to publishing consistent, high-quality open data for your authority. Follow the 12 steps above and you will produce highly usable data which can generate significant impact for your authority as well as saving you time and money. But how can you let people know your data is high-quality?

In our next module, you will learn how standards help improve the quality of open data. You will also learn how to certify the quality of your datasets and encourage even greater use.
